comment: For some reason I can never get the fruitiness that everyone raves about. It always lands more earthy than I’m expecting, and that effects my enjoyment. Will try again soon and update.

First Japanese whiskey. Light, sweet, and fruity nose. Starts off with sweet vanilla/apple taste then moves to a more floral and peppery finish with more heat than I was expecting. Good alternative option to bourbon.
Clean. Most flavors listed are muted but to be fair I didn’t do it correctly

Nose: honeysuckle, pear, hints of apple, very faint scents of peat. Smells sweet like a bourbon. 

Palate: fruity and floral. Notes of apple and grapefruit. Some peat and earth, but not prominent. Mouthfeel is thin.

Finish: Dry and lingering. Oak and grapefruit. Faint notes of grain. 

Overall: GOOD. Very similar to Glenlivet 12 with a thinner mouthfeel and more floral/fruity notes. An available and accessible choice for those looking for a good Japanese whisky.
Sweet,  fruity,  light with a hint of smoke,  subtle and smooth,  definitely enjoyable
very good but very light, wouldn't dare mixing it with anything but ice.
Smooth, great finish, a little too sweet

The first Japanese whiskey that I've tried. The first thing you notice is how light in color the whiskey is. The nose is very faint with some vanilla, ripe green fruit, and a light lysol-lemon scent. The taste has a bit more of the vanilla with a little bit of a minty, pine flavor. This is super smooth, and the finish is virtually non-existent. I prefer a bit more of a punch with the taste and finish, but it is nice easy sipper overall.
Sweet, clingy, strong ethanol burn with thin aftertaste. Makes a good cocktail base for Boulevardiers etc.
Slightly sweet, floral, light, goes down smooth. Looks like White wine, hits hard later!
Nice! Bright, fresh, floral, sweet, light, honey, green fruit, green tea, young but soft, lingers well. Like it a lot!
the alcohol burn was there. was served with a cherry and orange

Great sub $50 whiskey.

You can tell this is a very young whiskey but that doesn't mean it's not filled with robust and distinctive notes.

On the nose you get a very light and floral butter and banana toffee.

On the other hand the palate is very short and hints with a slight pepper and white sugar finish.
Sweet and refreshing with a nice bit of heat

Just go and buy a bottle. You’ll thank me! Apples, vanilla and deliciously creamy. Almost like a candy sweetness and then an incredible lengthy finish that is truly another sensational Japanese whisky.
Almost like a scotch west highland. 6th try. Gosling

Smell strongly of pear, and other sugar fruits, more alcohol than I was thinking. 

After adding an ice cube the smell opened dramatically and fruit notes mellowed slightly and added a walnut smell. The taste mellowed but wasn't lost.

Tastes like seaweed, young grain, asparagus, and overextracted green tea.

Tried it with some soda water in a classic "Japanese highball", still disappointing.

If you're on a budget and want to try a Japanese whisky, don't bother with Toki.
The smell leads you to believe it will be harsh but it's smooth with a bit of burn on the back end.
Not as smooth as hibiki harmony. One note of flavor.
Fruity: apples and pears. Light finish with fruit lingering
Mild sweet taste. slight burn finish.
Honey and floral on the nose. The taste reminds me a lot of an Irish whiskey until the finish which is very spicy and long lasting. Nice for the price!
Just an easy drinker. Rich and fruity.. lighter in body but full flavor. This will be a regular in my collection.

Hard to give this 5/5 based on each of my friends unknowingly suggesting the same thing upon my brag of the purchase of Suntory Toki: "Oh, man. You gotta try Hibiki." So the consensus is that Hibiki is the top notch, but Suntory Toki was my first Japanese whisky, as it is for many given it is perhaps the cheapest. I loved it. I could chug it, gargle it, savor it. There are various notes on the fruit side, but predominantly pear and macintosh apple (do not expect granny smith on this, there is nothing sour about it) mixed with a smoky, woody flavor, but said smoke & wood flavors are merely accents to the fruity, botanical ones. If you are searching for a new whisky around $40, do not settle for the same old- try Suntory Toki. This bottle is addicting in the best way.
Very light fruity with whiskey with a slight sweet caramel. Classic whiskey smell on the nose and very soft mild finish on the taste. Easy to drink all night!
Full bodied with hint of herb, not much fragrant, not my favorite
A hint of smoke on the finish. I am picking up floral and fruity notes.

Considering the price - this I another Suntory quality example. Light blend, both in color and taste, with a very charming aftertaste. Try it on the porch during a warm summer evening while thinking about your life.

Agreed with a lot of reviews.  Sweet, light, green apples and unripe pears.  Honey.  Slight hint of peat smoke.  Very short finish.  I’d have to guess this will be the majority of what to expect from Japan until their new stock matures for 6-10 more years .

I don’t know why, but I feel this whisky would be so much better on a summer evening/night. It has a light and airy feel that reminds me of summer. This blend is best with a few ice cubes and a splash of low sodium club soda. The flavors are summery and brilliant.
Grape on the nose. Light honeydew and a touch of smoke twine into a tight bitter finish. Not in love, but godammit I respect its sensitivity.
Love it.  Light whiskey.  Great for a Highball.
Grainy. Smooth, yet complex. Reminiscent of a full-bodied Irish whiskey.
Unique flavor profile...combination of several flavors/styles...I like this
Good. Smooth. Don't remember much else....
pale lime yellow colour, light body floral, honey, grean tea and some earth flavours.

Nose: Apple, pear
Taste: Buttery, floral, smoke finish
This was a really old, opened bottle
Solid choice for the price. Smooth taste with sweet and spicy finish. Does very well alone (suggested) or in a light mixture.
Fantastic everyday whisky at a great price point
Lemon, dusty corn, nail polish remover, and slight oak on the nose. Oaky lemon, grains,  and soft barrel spice on the taste. Long and light alcohol burn with oak on the finish.
melon, green apple and slight cereal on the nose, spicy, creamy vanilla on the palate, warm medium finish.
Sweet and rich, would get again if the price isn’t too high
You can definitely taste the sweetness.  Mild heat on the back makes this enjoyable.

Nose: Right off the back pear and other fruitiness. Little bit of oak and general clean smell.
Taste: Fruit, oak
Finish: Subtle spice on the way down
Light. Reminds me of Glenmorangie 10 year

Banana pudding, Oak/smoke, oil/butter, vanilla and cinnamon.  Heat and spice comes in the middle, then the long finish is sweet and floral.  Butter and strawberries.  More like a scotch than an American bourbon.  Lighter bodied but not weak. Clean but not too simple.  Honey, whipped cream and mandarin orange emerge as the mouth nerves dull from the alcohol.  Smooth and easy to sip.  Agreeable and not overly feisty.

The nose is very straightforward and is primarily just ethanol with hints of oak and sweet corn. The palate is primarily spicy cloves and sweet vanilla. It lingers only briefly closing with mainly hints of oak and sweet corn with a medicinal alcohol flavor dominating. A very simple, non-memorable but drinkable dram.

On the nose kind of caramel, honey and fruity. On the tongue, fruity, honey, a touch medicinal, deceptively spicy and surprisingly hot. A fruity finish lingers a bit. Good but not great and a bit overrated.
Rice and light smoke in the nose. Light malt with light smoke flavor. Light and pleasant overall.
Fruity and slightly peaty. Very good especially for the price
Fruity on the nose and sipping. Smooth all around. Really enjoyed
Earthy with notes of apple on the nose. Very smooth.
apple, ginger, honey, minty on the finish
Honey, lemon, and pear on the nose. Light grassy finish with lingering honey. Would definitely buy again

First taste of anything Japanese alcohol (except for some Sake back in the day). Nosing for me always brings difficulty. I do get a something that might be marshmallow, slight marzipan, etc. along with the green fruit of apples, pears and light citrus. On the tongue it is all lightly malted sweet candy with no discernible burn. Finish is medium but the sweetness remains. 

For the price this is such easy sipping. I'm sure the higher priced Yamazaki, Oishi offerings here in PA are worth the money. But for easy sippin' this is hard to beat. I'm a full two fingers into this 750ml and it is difficult to believe this is 86 proof. Feels more like 80 ... but it may have delayed hit due to it's light mouthfeel and thin weight, despite respectable legs in the Glencairn.

I put this in the same class as the Knappogue Castle 12 year in terms of cost, overall value and taste but I prefer the Irish for a few dollars more.

PA $40 but on sale at $36.

Clear, medium lemon; clean, light intensity, cereal, red apple skin, jasmine, thyme, char, short aged; dry, smooth, medium body, medium intensity, Corn Pops, sweet hay, baked apple, long finish, some complexity; good quality
Mild nose, scotch like taste, fast and light finish.
Almost drinks like a scotch. Light.
Well rounded notes of basil, thyme, and vanilla. Not intense and pleasant. Like a well mannered roommate, little investment and a minor boon.
Love sipping this sweet little nectar, especially when drinking out of the decorative glass that comes in the box.

I really like this one.  It starts off with some alcohol heat, but that gives way to a really nice honey flavored sweetness.  I didn't get a lot of complexity in the flavor, but if you like sweet whiskys, this is definitely worth a try.
nice and easy whisky, but laks a bit of body.

cornflakes, Belgian trippel, sweet fruit, phenols and esters.
warm sweet front with a bit of spice and light grains on the finish some cobwebs and semi sweet hay
Buttery, vanilla, and hints of honey. Smooth and lively finish, no heat

Light, almost no nose (?) but extremely smooth. Lack of a strong nose contributes to the lightness in taste, but it definitely has its appeal. Reasonably refreshing and a lot of similarities to true scotch without the peatiness or brineyness normally associated with scotches.
lighter than Jameson, fruity, hint of rice wine
Makes a great highball.  Not so good on its own.
Very hard with limited flavor notes

Pale straw color, barely yellow. Clear, chill-filtered, with light viscosity. Nose is weak, with hints of vanilla, oak, and some fruit on the back. Palate is very smooth and light, with fresh apple, pear, touch of caramel, honey, and a hint of meadow flowers. Finish is short dominated by sweetness. A few drops of water do very little for this 43% ABV whisky but maybe somewhat intensify sweetness. Overall, this is a very easy dram that does not really impress in any particular way and lacks complexity. It may be OK for $30, but I’d rather get the Monkey Shoulder if on a budget.
Smooth, very light peat and smoke, maybe some caramel
Very simple whiskey that hits you up front but doesn’t linger
Caramel with a hint of black licorice
Lightly fragrant. Sweet and a bit spicy and peppery on the finish. Very light in color.

Finished this bottle a couple months ago and into my foray of searching for my next whiskey I was reminded by how I enjoyed this bottle so decided to write my quick review after reminiscing. 
As a drinker of scotch and bourbon the first thing I noticed was how soft this was when first sipping it. Very inoffensive taste that went well with a small cube. Sweeter profile than any scotch I’ve had in the past. For under $30 and my inexperience in relatively pricier Japanese whiskies out there I certainly would recommend this bottle. 

9/8/19

Nose: vanilla, honey, caramel, lemon, orange, pear, slight cake malt
Taste: lemon, very very light peat, pear, apple, cake malt, honey, rosemary, parsley, 

I feel this gets looked over a lot because its a readily available Japanese whiskey and they let the hype take over. This is no Harmony or a single malt for sure and its a bit young, but it is good, especially for $30 or under. Treat it like a budget highland or speyside scotch rather than some mystical Japanese product and it'll be good

I reviewed this one about a year ago. Gave it a 4, but was pretty non-descript in my otherwise. Saw it on sale a month back and decided to bring this one back into the home bar. It was my first Japanese whisky back then, let's see a year of experience and an updated rating system change my original score.

Nose: Young and grainy. Lots of cereal. Big malt and toffee notes. Orange peel, green apple, vanilla, and honey. A pinch of black pepper and basil. Some almond and even shortbread cookie. Surprisingly a bit astringent.

Palate: More orange and now some grapefruit and lemon. Much more bitter than I remember. Big cereal grains. More vanilla and honey sweetness, with an artificial green apple Jolly Rancher note. A bit of milk chocolate and more malt. Both bitter and sweet, as well as young and grainy.

Finish: Orange and grapefruit still come through. There's more milk chocolate, vanilla, and honey, and then a burst of cinnamon, pepper, and oak. I get a soapy note somewhere along the way, and roasted nuts on the tail end. Moderate in length. Best part of the dram.

Not quite how I remembered it. It's fine, and it offers solid VFM. When I wrote my last review, I wrote something to the effect of, "This was interesting enough to get me to explore the genre of Japanese of whisky." And it succeeded in doing so.

After trying the Hibiki Harmony, I can't deny that that is head and shoulders above this one. To peg it at double the price of this Toki is fair in my opinion. This one hits  it's mark at its price point and is worth a shot. Definitely a worthy gateway to Japanese whisky, as it was for me. Great choice if you're looking to get into Japanese whisky or if you just want to try something new and are on a budget.

After a subsequent tasting, I was definitely a bit harsh on this one. Must have been an off night. Bumping the 3 to a 3.5.
Nice whiskey.  Seems a little young.  Is much better aged a bit longer.
Not Smokey at all light and alcoholic
Very light in color. Boozy up front, delicate on the back end. Not sweet, bit of smoke.

Very scotchy and smooth. Great Neat much more diverse with a few drops of spring water. Cinnamon vanilla, and amazing oaks. Best sipping experience was when I poured it over reusable ice cubes and swirled it around. Amazing vanilla and pear flavors very enjoyable experience

Very scotchy and smooth. Great Neat much more diverse with a few drops of spring water. Cinnamon vanilla, and amazing oaks. Best sipping experience was when I poured it over reusable ice cubes and swirled it around. Amazing vanilla and pear flavors very enjoyable experience
喝起来甚至不像是威士忌lol，更像伏特加。清爽的像是泡在气泡水里的小青瓜。拿toki冷萃了正山小种~意外的惊喜！茶味和威士忌味混合的超级棒！
Mellow and smooth. Seems to have a rice aftertaste, but that could be my predilection for sake speaking. Good for lighthearted sipping.

I knew this was a light whisky, but I greatly underestimated just how light it would be. To me, it tasted like an even more watered-down Jameson. I wouldn't say it's bad, but it's a poor representation of what Japan has to offer.
Reminds me of what you would get as well whisky at a bar
Clean whiskey. Notes of crisp apple and thyme. Fresh, easy sipper

For someone who is largely a bourbon drinker this just comes across is totally different. First of all the color is a pale straw. I was surprised how much the nose hits me a foot away from the glass as pale as it is!

It may just be a mental association between the pale color and apple juice but that is absolutely the first thing to hit my nose. Bringing it a little closer I almost get an Apple cider vinegar. There is also quite a bit of sweet malt, something like I would expect from an Irish whiskey.  Sniffing and I seem to pick up something like new oak. I don’t get much in the way of anything nutty, earthy or spicy.

The pallet has a tingle of a burn but is largely overwhelmed by malty sweetness.  Mouth feel is pretty thin and the finish the short and dry. Now back at the nose I wonder if I pick up a little bit of heather and honey, but I could just totally making this up.

The second sip is smoother, with a little bit more of the honey sweetness coming across as well as maybe raisins or dried fruit. I don’t get much in the way of oak the first few sips but as I continue to drink on I feel like towards the end of the pallet maybe I pick up the Japanese oak?

Do I enjoy it? Absolutely!  Would I jump up and shout “this is Japanese!” Doubtful. Regardless I will enjoy finishing this bottle.
Very light. Floral and slightly sweet. Almost has a green tea aspect.
Very light colored. Sweet flavored.  Nice to sip and not overly harsh or complex.
Very smooth with a buttery nose and start. Not much finish.
Smooth start with a long lingering slow burn at the end. A little sweet, pleasant oily taste. Good whiskey neat.
Like it a lot. Kinda like what I feel when I have a tasty, flavorful beer. This is a tasty whisky. Kinda reminds me of wheat beer. Not the flavor but the feel

Thin fast legs, yellow almost clear 

Grain, rice sweet, almost no alcohol burn on nose. 

Peaty, meaty, oily,
Sweet, zensty, cinnamon, soft and easy to drink.... Maybe too easy but good if your not into Islay scotch.
Bright, slight burn followed by smooth finish.  Slight honey
Guess I need to try more Japanese whisky, this was very good. If you like Glenmorangie 10, you’re gonna love this.

This is the first Japanese Whiskey I’ve tried. I’m normally tasting Bourbons, so this will be a fun change. This was in a flight of whiskeys at a tasting.

On the nose I get green banana, some floral notes, and a little vanilla. This reminds me of Scotch. It also really reminds me a lot of Nelson’s Green Brier Tennessee Whiskey, which is a totally different category, but it is reminiscent.

The palate is a continuation of the nose. It’s a little sweet with some dusty notes.

This has a medium short dry finish, with some floral notes fading away.

Overall this was fun to try. It really does remind me of Scotch, though I haven’t had a ton of those either. It’s a fairly light and gentle whiskey and a good introduction into Japanese whiskey.

My first Japanese Whisky and a solid one to start. Light and smooth and fruity, buttery shortbread and small hints of pear to the taste. Heavily floral on the nose and to the taste as well, very similar to Irish but delicious nonetheless
On flavor alone this is 4/5, but it is incredibly drinkable, incredibly versatile, and makes the best highball out there. I always have a bottle on hand.
Sweet honey notes. Oak, pepper, citrus flavor with a small bite. Mellows with ice.
A little bit of a bite and peaty
Alcohol on the nose. Very light and floral. Hits the front of tongue with alcohol, but doesn’t linger. Very floral and light. Ends with a grape-like acidity.

Sweet malty aroma, light grain sweetness. 
Light grain and wood flavor, blends together very nicely. Medium richness despite how light it is. Medium tail, super approachable.
A lot of apple and cinnamon on the nose with a very smooth finish that ends with a bit of oakiness. A few drops of water really opens it up
Sweet and floral after note, slightly floral and oaky on the nose

Had this in a Suntory tasting involving toki components, Harmony components, legent, and ao. This is ok with notes of Apple, Pear, Vanilla, Honey, Mint, Grass, Caramel, Floral notes, and slightly Peated. This was presented alongside a lightly Peated Hakushu malt and a Chita heavy grain. 

Lightly Peated Hakushu: Green Apple, Marshmallow, Vanilla, Pear, Mint, Citrus, Apricot. This is the Toki's main component

Chita Heavy Grain: Vanilla, Grassy, Corn, Caramel, Citrus, Marshmallow, Floral, Mint, Cotton Candy

Liked the Chita heavy grain component the most and the parts outweighed the sum.
Easy sipping whiskey over ice. Light and fruity.

Not bad for my first Japanese. Floral, vanilla on the nose. Low ethanol smell. More floral, nutty, when tasting. Decent feel with medium finish. Lingering cinnamon like feel in the end. Nice pour but wouldn’t buy again.

Bottle poured into a snifter at home, neat. Nice clear light golden yellow color. Aroma and flavor includes malt, corn, wheat, a little caramel, a slight toasty/smoky note, touch of alcohol. Subtle apple-like flavor. Nice, easy sipper.
Light bodied with a floral nose, followed by a hit  of citrus on the palate. Lasting finish with a bit of spice. A good blend.
Green apples, green tea, slight spice that ends very smooth. I paid 36 dollars which is excellent value for money. Great intro to Japanese whisky, and I highly recommend it!

I wasn't the biggest fan of this on my previous tasting, but I really think it opened up this time. A lot more sweetness on the nose with a lot of green tea and apple, a really unique smell. The taste is really pretty on this one with just a hint of smoke on the backend. Definitely not an everyday whiskey for me but still a very unique whiskey that I quite enjoyed on this tasting.

Nose is freshly peeled green pear with an effervescent note of red apple. Flavor is thin and underwhelming compared to the nose. It begins with an oaken vanilla but finishes with a astringent hydrogen peroxide bite.

Found this at Costco for $30. Came in a box set with a couple highball glasses and ice cube trays.

Drank it neat and found it light with some fruitiness. Green apple and honey is what I tasted. It was decent and refreshing. 

Tried in a highball next. A recipe was included on the box set. I enjoyed it very much and makes a satisfying cocktail.

I’m tasting apples, biscuits, and tea.  I think a lot of people that don’t like whiskey could enjoy this.  It’s smooth and has a floral finish.  Some burn but not bad.  Price is also very low for such decent quality.  A must try and one I will always keep around.
Floral nose, oak on palette with growing caramel and brown sugar. A saltiness shows up towards the end.

Light and sweet. Almost creamy and soft at first, but with a bright finish.

Sweeter than I care for.

This is my first Japanese whiskey. Color is a very light gold, almost like a white wine. Nose is light and sweet; honey and vanilla with a slight oaky undertone. Palate is similarly light and sweet; smooth and fruity. Finish carries the warm oak. This whiskey is  reminiscent of a speyside scotch in my initial opinion. Overall smooth and light.
Reminds me of an Irish whiskey.  Great for the $ and could easily be a daily drinker.

Nose: light toffee, caramel, 

Taste : powdered sugar , light caramel, tart, short floral heat on finish.

Didn’t know what to expect with this one, but was pleasantly surprised. Enjoyed the short heat in finish.
My first foray into Japanese Whisky at Blue Pit. A smooth and sweet flavor profile with notes of honey and lemongrass. Would prefer something more bold but still quite enjoyable

Reminds me of my most hated tequila. 
Cuervo.
Elegant. Light. Herbal with slight floral note. Quick finish.
A very light and easy whisky. Love it. Friendly to anyone new.
Gyümölcsös illat, kicsit acetonos, csípősebb íz, különleges

Floral, fruity.. a bit too much alcohol

A good whisky to have in a bar.. Far from a yamazaki or a hibiki

Follow me on instagram: @whiskperience
Fruity and full. Floral on the nose
Simple and smooth in touch, and not so much burn. A hint of honey-like sweetness as after taste
It's fine. Not too harsh, lighter
I love this. Will always have a specifically place in my heart as I first had it on a wonderful European vacation and it got me interested in whiskey
This was much lighter than I expected...in a good way. This is just very easy to drink. Nothing else to add. Just a good pour.

My first adventure with Japanese whiskey.  Very light in color so prepared myself for a thin favor.  Couldn't be more wrong.  Taste is sweet upfront with a little pepper midway.  Warming through the finish.  Nose is earthy, grass comes through as well. My lips are tinkling!

I think this is definitely an underrated whisky from Suntory. Just because it's under $30 doesn't mean it's not a good whisky. I think I might have to stock up on them before they become the next Yamazaki or Hakushu and skyrocket in price.
First Japanese Whisky. Apple. Sweet. Smooth. Pleasantly surprised. Great whisky for those looking to get into them.
A bit of salt in the finish
Not bad. Fruity smell with a touch of maybe banana. Smooth but a subtle peaty flavor that reminds me of Irish. Not really my thing.

Nose - honey, apples, pears, light vanilla and caramel, light ethanol burn. 

Taste - honey, light caramel, butterscotch, pears, creme brûlée, mild alcohol burn, finishing quick and creamy sweet.

Easy sipper. Reminds me of a speyside.
Very clean. A fresh and crisper whiskey. Botanical notes.
Great taste with a sweet finish
This is quite good, anytime sippable, and affordable to boot.
Great intro to Japanese whiskey. Light notes of oak, honey, vanilla, and maybe ginger or florals. Almost reminda me of some Irish whiskeys

Nose: Fruity, sweet, vanilla
Palate: Pear, apples, honey
Finish: quick, a little spicy
Vanilla and toffee nose, and a big ethanol scent. Really nice in a highball.
Remarkably good for the price. Not as good as the Nikka Coffey Grain that started your love affair with Japanese whisky, but definitely one to always have on hand.
Some apple and other bright stone fruit and grain flavor. Light spice on the finish.
Apple notes in the beginning ending with nutty notes. Dry at the end also.

It’s Friday and the world is in utter turmoil.  Health, humanity and survival (economically) are on most minds (at least mine on this Friday, first day of spring).  Tonight a small, brief escape with a sample provided what now seems a hundred years ago by SDT brethren @LeeEvolved. 

It pours light-straw in color.  Now, it’s an later September afternoon. Not too hot. You’re standing in the middle of an Apple orchard.  That is the base aroma.  Pears and apricots mixed in with golden honey, tea, straw and a smidge of nutmeg. 

The palate and flavors are very similar to Glenlivet 12.  Sweetness of honey, vanilla, caramel, lemon, Granny Smith apples. There is a prickle of cinnamon and ginger spice near as it finds it’s way to the finish. 

The palate holds a finish of citrus grapefruits and orange zest.  Bits of wood and the bitterness of dark chocolate that lasts for, surprisingly, a good length of time. 

A simple bit of enjoyment at an extremely affordable price.  Aromatic and with solid flavors.  A good, light, easy sipper. Sometimes in life a bit of simplicity and straightforwardness can be rewarding.  In recent days like these, when you’re tired of thinking and worrying, a small escape, yet for a brief time, is sometimes the best tonic. [85/100][Tasted: 3/20/20]
Mild but good. Not too much depth
This is nice. This is smooth. Perfectly easy to sip on the rocks with no friction.

Nose: sweet/fruity
Mouth: sweet apple/honey, little spice
Finish: very quick, grapes?
Don't be a snob. For 40 bucks, this is a steal.
Light and sweet, smell of apples, not a bad blended whisky not a great blended whisky

Nose: honey / sunflowers

Taste: pears, warm vanilla, honey. Tastes like a warm spring day.

Nose: light, caramel, hint of pear
Taste: sweet, honey, chocolate, some spice
Finish: warm spices, some eucalyptus
Citrus on the nose. Light, floral palate. A bit high and some heat on the tongue. Nice sipper
Spicy end, would recommend to people who don’t like whisky
Spicy on the end, very easy drinking up until the end. Could make a non-whiskey drinker interested IMO
Nice smooth start, ends with quiet spicy tone
Very sweet and slightly fruity with a spicy finish
Super doux. Arrière goût de vanille.

Straw yellow color with some sticky legs. The nose is red Apple skins and pear. Just a hint of tobacco. It's mostly fruit rinds and vanilla. The nose is firmly in the Scotch tradition. With a droplet some boiled vegetable sulphurics pop out.

The Apple skins and pear continue into the front of the palate. Has a very sweet, puckery second moment, like the syrup from an apple pie. Touch of leather. The burn is there but really dovetails nicely with some cigar tobacco. There is a fruity pucker that keeps coming back.

The finish is more tobacco, with a touch of smoke that tastes like a match that just went out. All those fruity parts evaporate and leave some smoke behind. This is a deceptively complex Scotch clone, I'll be back to it.

Another Japanese Whisky, another gem. This is the cheaper Blend from Suntory, but it is still made from yamazaki, chita and Hakushu, just as Hibiki is. 

Bottled at 43%, pale straw Color.

On the nose, it is very fresh,  with acetone, lemon peel, fresh lime, floral and chocolate notes. 

On the palate it is just wonderful, chocolate and toffee for a nano-second, then a strong tobbacco and dry grass note to end in this ultra powerful and spicy finish (clove and pepper).

The finish is so long it might just be the longest finish i have ever tasted in a whisky. Amazing.

Overall i give this dram a 94 over 100 and it is a must, specially for the price. Cheers!
Very smooth. No astringent flavors. Sweet.
Light whisky. Nice and smooth. Great lingering malt flavor.
Smells better than it taste. Different kind of spice but has a sweetness
Great for sipping. I really enjoy the nose.  Easy to drink.  Prefer neat
Nice litlle peat smell. Pears, citrus notes. Honey notes in mouth.
The nose is tropical fruits, moving in the direction of pineapples. It's floral on the tase, and the pineapple comes back in a big way on the warming, lingering finish.
Light, almost tea-like. Drank right after the brown sugar bomb that is knob creek

Fruit and spice on the nose, with a medium viscosity body. More fruit and a little heat on the finish. Was initially a little underwhelmed by this one, but it grew on me. Not nearly as cloyingly sweet as the Sherry cask finish. Easy drinking.
Hints of apple and vanilla with a strong floral finish.

Nose : delicate, floral, hint of caramel
Taste: sweetish, some pepper
Finish : slight burn, honey

GLASS:
Dalmore Glencairn Copita Nosing Glass

NOSE:
Neat - Pretty simple. Green tea and pear. Overly hot (alcohol) and unbalanced. 

PALATE:
Neat - Consistent with the nose. Pear and green tea. The finish is a little short.. Lacks a happy ending. 

CONCLUSION:
Was a pass until I saw the price. Now I’m willing to make out with it under the bleachers. No commitments. 
$39.99 USD per Bottle
Sweet with a hint of smoke. Very subtle overall. Enjoyed with a large ice cube after letting it melt down a little.
Not particularly smooth, the flavor reminds me most of sour apples, the aftertaste is good, but the front is a lot to overcome
Light and sweet. Not much on the nose. Honey and vanilla on the palate. No burn, short finish. Pretty good.
Nice blend, a bit sweet with some hints of smoke. Not overly capricious. 😁🥃
Balanced and smooth.  Although a few off notes, still enjoyable
Very interesting, confusing with the progression of flavors, the "swisher sweet cigar" of whiskeys... bold but sweet but i aint mad at the finish

Different! Lighter. Does not taste like it smells. Compare it to smoking a swisher sweet: it has a sweet but musty funk part way through, but then finishes light. Feels like it doesn’t know what it wants to do. Actually enjoyed the aftertaste the most. Began to like it more as I drank it. Would not buy, but would love tasting with a friend.
too much like scotch for my liking

How time flies.  The first and, really, the only time I'd heard of Suntory was in the 2003 movie, "Lost in Translation" starring Bill Murray and the recent breakthrough actress, Scarlett Johansson. Over a decade later, in 2018, Johansson became the highest paid actress on the planet.  That very same year I began to treat whiskey-drinking like the spectator sport it is.  A re-encounter was inevitable. I started searching for new whiskies to try (and add to my collection), when I read about a Japanese one with a familiar name,  'Suntory'?  Then it dawned on me, that's a real life whiskey!  In 2003 when I had watched the movie, I assumed that this was a fictionalized brand. Still, I relegated the real life Suntory to the back of my mind, just as I had done the film.  There were just too many bourbons, scotches, and other alternatives to try first.  That is until recently, when @jonwilkinson7309 and I discussed a sample trade. Jumping out of that list was a Suntory, as attention demanding as the gleam on a katana blade.  I didn't think twice - didn't even resist... 'Sign me up!'  

Now going into this, I had high hopes. [Not that I'd hope about much if I smoked dope.... isn't that the obvious reason people get high.... the apparent absence of hope?.. most of the time, except when I'm not drinking, I just hope to get high for free.  But that probably isn't going to happen..  crooked health insurers.]  Yeah, I thought this would be all gang-busters, shoot-em outs with one Yakuza clan going after another.  But the reality was not so.  

On the nose: orchard fruits and vanilla. Youth also appears as ethanol.  Youth then rears its head on the palate as well. It tastes hot, hotter than the stated 43% ABV. The flavor comes across as almost citrus-y at first sip.  DOH!  The alcohol heat, however, drops the initial citrus lollipop deterring it from turning effervescent. Follow on sips bear the palate and brain toward apples, pears, and vanilla.  The higher ABV doesn't add much body, as the mouthfeel is a tad watery, but it does add to the heat. (Is it hot yet?) The finish is actually medium in length with a bit of drying woodchip.  Adding water flattens the palate and body, but cools the heat down while muting the wood notes.  Very fleeting, and one-note.  I attempted to pull more flavor or texture out of this with a big swishing sip.  But that still eluded me.  It was very much like trying to tell a cat to 'Stay'.  Good luck with that!  True, this is missing the sophistication of a deeper-aged single malt. But, perhaps, I'm being overly critical here.  All in all, a decent, light summer dram. I dare say, as an alternative to a traditional Old World whisky -- you could do worse.  While the memory of this sip will get lost in the fog of time, the memory of the film and the Suntory brand will continue.  Thanks @jonwilkinson7309 for my first encounter with J-whisky. I enjoyed the exchange!  Tasted from a full 50ml sample.


My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
Good and smooth. I taste tobacco and grain
Easy on the nose. Light and crisp, minimal bite with wet, almost refreshing finish.

Nose: floral, ripe stone fruits - pear and peach, hint of smoke, 
Palate: light airy floral notes, sweet pear, hunt black pepper, smoke. acclimated quickly to the lovely floral notes. Left with more earthy notes
Finish: lingers in the throat with light pepper, smoke, and light pear sweetness

Nose: Light floral and fruity. A little fermentation funk almost like grapes fermenting.

Taste: a little heat on the tip of the tongue. Sweet pear and apple. Alcohol warm finish

Nose: fresh citrus, marsipan, some aceton, slightly salty
Taste: sweetish, raisins, surprisingly spicy, pure chocolate
Finish: warm, some chocolate & spices

Light and fruity, with a bit of a pepper note. Easy to drink and a great whisky for the price. 

A good one to bring out when you have a mate over to watch the game, but you don’t want to crack open the expensive bottle because the cheapskate didn’t bring anything with him and has already polished off 4 of your beers.

Nose: Dark chocolate and Bing cherry (like the chocolates)
Palette: Peatty taste - like a light scotch.
Finish: the peattiness sticks around with a slight taste of leather.  Not a strong finish.
